qas.question: In the Mahayana, who is thought to be an omnipresent being?
Who is thought to be beyond the range and reach of thought?
In what sutras are the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha viewed as One?

context: In the <a2_0>Mahayana<a2_0/>, the <a0_0><a1_0>Buddha<a1_0/><a0_0/> tends not to be viewed as merely human, but as the earthly projection of a beginningless and endless, omnipresent being (see Dharmakaya) beyond the range and reach of thought. Moreover, in certain Mahayana sutras, the Buddha, Dharma and Sangha are viewed essentially as One: all three are seen as the eternal Buddha himself.
